comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Re Fred Walmsley, I found a snippet in the Sunday Independent from Sunday, 1 August 1909: "
... To supply special attractions for the holiday season next week several favourites are returning to the Kingstown Pavilion, including Fred Walmsley, the versatile comedian, whose character sketches and songs are so immensely popular..."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The OSNI doesn't have the bandstand marked on the 6" in 1902 but does on the 1919 25"

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/8776679149/ (Thier map viewer is a complete pain!)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Interesting it's not on the 1902 map! Any way that could be an error on the cartographer's part? (Probably not)

I really thought this one was earlier than 1900. But could it then be after 1902 and up to 1914 (latest date for Lawrence photos)??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: The bandstand (on the prom) would have only been there from around 1902 if the minutes we have from then are correct: "10 February 1902 Mr Cox of Liverpool applied for and got permission to erect a small stage for a troupe of musicians on the promenade during the summer" www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&... I'll post that photo on the forum now and see if it generates any more comments :-) (also, any Warrenpoint stuff gratefully received) :-)

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: This blurry Screen grab from an "old Warrenpoint" video states that the Great Northern Hotel- with turret- was built by the railway company in 1899. While I cannot assume that it was there when your photo was taken i feel looking at the other NLI William Mervin photo I linked earlier, the costumes, grass marks, fountain spill would suggest that it was. i.e. both photos taken at the same time. post 1899.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/brian_mccalmont] What a fantastic resource! Wish we had minutes online for all UDCs around the country.

I searched down through the minutes just looking for "band" and it looks to me (assuming this was quite a permanent structure in this photo) that it wasn't erected until 1907?? (Unless there was another bandstand elsewhere in Warrenpoint?

P.S. Thanks for posting on forum and other Warrenpoint photos now on list...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] I'll take your suggestion gladly and amend to 1899 as earliest date...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] That's the one in the park. You can see it in the 1919 map above but the park isn't even a park yet in 1902.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Dead right, and thanks for the reminder! 1902 to 1914 then...

(Plus thanks for not yelling D'oh at me - sometimes juggling a lot of balls in the air at this end. Perhaps I should perform on The Promenade at Warrenpoint...)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content:
"3rd July 1905
A man called Tuling given permission to entertain on promenade. A bandstand for the promenade was proposed. "

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: There is also a mention in June 1908 for the removal of the bandstand on the promenade (by this stage the park bandstand would be in full operation) I Know the Municipal park bandstand was erected in 1907 by Walter Macfarland & Co. Saracan Foundry in Glasgow.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: possibly 1905 - 1914 then (unless there was a particularly nostalgic surveyor involved in the production of the1919 map, the great bandstand removal proposal of 1908 failed).

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brian_mccalmont] Your previous suggestion of a temporary 1902 bandstand may be better. Neither the bandstand nor the fountain appear very well built or permanent looking. The roof isn't level on the bandstand.

comment.author: 51588910@N08
91549360@N03
comment._content: I see no sprocket or chain? Looks like it could be shaft drive bicycle. They were a fashion late 1800's ... long dresses and chains don't go too well!! www.coopertechnica.com/_image/1899-Columbia-Model-59-Shaf...

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: Argh, how can I add a note? I see a particularly fine hat & parasol combination. It's that lady on the far left who's shading her eyes.

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: This may help, in the far left hand corner I can see behind the people in the distance the unmistakable outline of the Municipal baths. The baths were first opened in June 1908 (and again after refurbishment) in 1909 so slowly but surely we are narrowing this down (a bit) :-)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: "Pierrots and Mr. Fred". that's your title right there. Sounds like a fine evening out!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brian_mccalmont] Yes, the baths are not on the 1902 map, but are on the 1919 as seen in DerangedLemur's images above. Well spotted!

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: There is an old map I have seen from 1906 that has the baths marked as being there, but it was a slight case of poetic license as the foundation stone was only laid on Monday August the 5th 1906 :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/brian_mccalmont] That definitely helps! So now 1908-1914...
